LOCATION: Knoxville, Tennessee USA

COMMENTS

Jack, you are one of my bass heroes, yet you are so much more than one of the greatest bassists who ever played the instrument. You are a seminal artist in the establishment of Rock, for all time. You created music that will continue to ring out and inspire in a world sorely lacking. Your incredible lines and amazing voice echo in hearts and minds across the world. Your legacy lives on - thank you for gracing us with such wonderful artistry!

NAME: David Vella

LOCATION: Saratoga Springs, New York

Email: dvella

[dot]: edu

Date: 28 Oct 2014

Time: 08:37:58

COMMENTS

Cream was my first musical love after the Beatles. Even to my young 14-year old ears, songs like 'As You Said' stood out above most of what else was happening in the music scene and had a profound effect on me and my future musical tastes. I've also enjoyed following Jack's career after Cream in it's many manifestations. I'm not a musician, but once about two or three years ago, I actually dreamed that I was jamming with Jack and apologizing for not being up to his standards. In my dream Jack was very kind and reassured me to just play what I feel and we had a blast together. Sure, it was only a dream, but it shows the extent to which Jack's music has affected me. Thank you Jack for placing the bar so high and for delivering years of invention, soul and skill in your music.

On October 18, 1968, I went to my first concert, the Cream farewell concert at the Forum in Los Angeles. I was just starting to play bass and had a '68 Jazz. After watching Jack play, I immediately went out and traded the Fender Jazz for a Gibson EB-3 (actually a very stupid move, I should have kept them both). But, from that time on, I was a Jack Bruce devotee and proceeded to learn all the Cream bass parts note for note. Always weird, interesting and challenging, he was the person who make me appreciate the potential of an instrument that sat in the back for so long. RIP Jack, to my greatest musical influence.

COMMENTS

One of the remarkable things about Jack - and here I mean Jack as Artist, since I've never had the good fortune to meet him in person (although living for decades with his works and voice in one's head can create an illusion that we 'know' him), is the way his example has inspired and illuminated the way for so many others. One need only skim these pages to see how many bass players were forged in the fires he enkindled with his work. Many of the greatest joys I've experienced in life have been the result of playing music, and every note I play has something to do with the lessons and values I've absorbed from following Jack's fearless artistic example - both as a creative role model on the instrument we both play and for his refusal to take the easiest path throughout his wide-ranging career. It would have been easy for him to simply continue doing what had made him most popular, and I'm deeply grateful to him for showing how to push beyond that to seek a series of new challenges. What I admire most in him, evidenced both through the things he played on his instrument and in his career choices, is his staunch determination not to be limited by the expectations of others. Jack Bruce, as revealed through his work, has been a huge presence in my interior life, and will surely continue to be so. I'm sorry we'll miss out on hearing whatever he was about to do next, because unlike many of his peers, he was still moving restlessly forward. My heart goes out to those of you who enjoyed real flesh-and-blood relationships with him, and for whom his loss exists in dimensions not available to people like myself who knew him only through his rich and wonderful music.
